Alexandros Marinos (is in Crete) on Twitter

item.title: Beware the GDP
item.description:
If you log on to the ‚ÄúEconomic Growth‚Äù page of ‚ÄúOur World in Data‚Äù it is easy to access estimates of GDP for over a hundred countries for the last two thousand years. These estimates are presented as fact. For example, right at the beginning of the first section titled ‚ÄúThe history of economic growth‚Äù it says in the third paragraph‚Ä¶

item.title: Chateaubriand and inequality: two centuries later
item.description:
I decided that my Summer reading‚Ä¶would be Chateaubriand‚Äôs memoirs (M√©moires d‚Äôoutre-tombe or in English Memoirs Beyond the Grave). I wanted to read them ever since I bought the books in the mid-1970. In the edition I have, the memoirs are published in three volumes (they are enormous). I read parts of volumes 1 or 2, but never touched volume 3. But now‚Ä¶

URL: https://branko2f7.substack.com/p/chateaubriand-and-inequality-two?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: In What Sense Was the Pre-Industrial Economy ‚ÄúMalthusian‚Äù?, &

item.title: Eternal as the Nile
item.description:
Egypt may technically be the world‚Äôs second-oldest literate civilization after Sumer, but in our imaginations, it lives on with a vivid grandeur Mesopotamia can‚Äôt touch. This owes to the incalculable influence Egypt exerted upon both Greeks and Hebrews, who deferred to the civilization of the Nile as more ancient and wiser than their own. Athenian democracy‚Äôs architect, the lawgiver Solon, reputedly traveled to Egypt to learn at the feet of its wise men. Plato in‚Ä¶

URL: https://razib.substack.com/p/eternal-as-the-nile?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: In What Sense Was the Pre-Industrial Economy ‚ÄúMalthusian‚Äù?, &

item.title: Come On, Man
item.description:
During the 2020 Democratic primary, Joe Biden told voters that as president, he‚Äôd get Republicans in line. A year-and-a-half out from his inauguration, it‚Äôs clear that hasn‚Äôt happened. He‚Äôs not up to the challenge.The Flashpoint is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber‚Ä¶

URL: https://eoinhiggins.substack.com/p/come-on-man?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Fed Overreacting?, & √æhe Post-1870 Speed of Transformation & Its Consequences, &

item.title: Most Americans Are Doing Well. For Now.
item.description:
The typical U.S. household earned more than ever as of May‚Äîeven after accounting for inflation. And their finances were secure, with consumer spending rising at a steady clip even as their saving rate remained elevated. This is being obscured by the misfortunes of America‚Äôs investors, who are being hit by huge tax payments owed on capital gains from 2021, falling asset values so far this year, and ongoing weakness in cash distributions via interest and dividends‚Ä¶

URL: https://theovershoot.co/p/most-americans-are-doing-well-for?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Fed Overreacting?, & √æhe Post-1870 Speed of Transformation & Its Consequences, &
